comments:
Finance 205 is designed to acquaint the student with the concepts of portfolio analysis in the general area of institutional investment management. The course discusses principles for managing financial assets. These principles apply, for example, to managing corporate pension funds, bank-administered trusts, and other institutional funds. Students will learn how to establish appropriate investment objectives, develop optimal portfolio strategies, estimate risk return tradeoffs, and evaluate investment performance. Many of the latest quantitative approaches are discussed.

Student opinion of this course was generally very strong. The course was “well-structured and well-taught,” and the material was “very interesting” and “worth knowing,” according to some. Students noted that the discussions of the latest research in investment management and the outside speaker sessions were engaging and enjoyable. Students found the portfolio management and investment strategies topics interesting, and one student pointed out that the course “provides a great overall introduction to various asset classes, which is very useful.”

Students described Professor Keim as “fantastic,” “very knowledgeable,” “extremely nice and agreeable,” and “a great lecturer.” One student stressed that he excelled at explaining the concepts and motivation behind all the models.” A handful of other students found lectures a little slow-moving.

Several students explained that exams were difficult and carried too much weight in the grading system. Some would have preferred less of an emphasis on fixed income, “considering we are offered a class in fixed income.”

The course discusses principles for managing financial assets. These principles apply, for example, to managing corporate pension funds, bank-administered trusts, and other institutional funds. Many of the latest quantitative approaches are discussed.

Student opinion of this course was generally very strong. The course was “well-structured and well-taught,” and the material was “very interesting” and “worth knowing,” according to some. Students noted that the discussions of the latest research in investment management and the outside speaker sessions were engaging and enjoyable. Students found the portfolio management and investment strategies topics interesting, and one student pointed out that the course “provides a great overall introduction to various asset classes, which is very useful.”

Students described Professor Keim as “fantastic,” “very knowledgeable,” “extremely nice and agreeable,” and “a great lecturer.” One student stressed that he excelled at explaining the concepts and motivation behind all the models.” A handful of other students found lectures a little slow-moving.

Finance 205 is designed to acquaint the student with the concepts of portfolio analysis in the general area of institutional investment management. The course discusses principles for managing financial assets. These principles apply, for example, to managing corporate pension funds, bank-administered trusts, and other institutional funds. Students will learn how to establish appropriate investment objectives, develop optimal portfolio strategies, estimate risk return tradeoffs, and evaluate investment performance. Many of the latest quantitative approaches are discussed.

Students were very satisfied with this course on the whole. One student found the course a “pleasurable learning experience” and emphasized that the case studies were especially relevant and useful. Another mentioned, “I would call this the best Finance class I’ve taken in Wharton.” Yet another stressed that the information on portfolio management and investment strategies was “insightful and practical.” One student commented, “Overall A+, no complaints.” 

Professor Stambaugh was praised across the board. Students explained that he was enormously well-versed in the course material and did “an unparalleled job in explaining things clearly,” and one cited the professor’s “unwavering ability to answer any/all questions in reference to subject material.” Many students were pleased with the professor’s commitment to encouraging student participation and appreciated that Professor Stambaugh learned everyone’s names. Negative feedback was extremely rare, but one student explained that more convenient office hours would have been beneficial.
